data.title: Expose context menu api in header toolbar area
data.body:
Sometimes, some extensions would has a lot of commands. It is not convenient for users to use key bindings or Command Palette. Therefore, it would be great that vscode could expose context menu api in header, so extension could put dozens of command in context menu of toolbar like [PlatformIO for Atom](https://github.com/platformio/platformio-atom-ide)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1050213/23786126/1f5919de-05a6-11e7-8b53-4232e7dec8d6.png)

data.title: Update PHP snippets
data.body:
This merge fixes syntax errors in the following snippets:

* $this->
* echo $this->
* function __construct
* do … while …
* while …
* switch …

Changed `'${1:variable}'` to `'${1:value}'` in `case` snippet to match `switch` snippet.

Add type hint and update default value for `function …` snippet.

Add type hint, `@return` and `@throw` PHPDoc elements, update default value, tab order and `@param` PHPDoc element for `PHPDoc function …` snippet.

Add accessor level and type hinting, and updated default value in `function __construct`.

Change `class …` to `PHPDoc class …` and remove constructor. Constructor removed in favor of updated `function __construct` snippet.

Remove generated function from `trait` snippet in favor of updated `function ...` and `PHPDoc function ...` snippets.

Create snippet `PHPDoc class …` that has a DocBlock.

Change name from `Class Variable` to `PHPDoc property`. Prefix remained the same.

Add `PHPDoc param …`.

Change order of snippets to group like snippets together.

data.title: Allow arguments for status bar item commands
data.body:
It should be possible to execute complex commands with the StatusBarItem. At the moment it is not possible to provide arguments for the command. Please adjust the interface like the recent change in v1.10 in the task key bindings:
```
{
    "key": "ctrl+h",
    "command": "workbench.action.tasks.runTask",
    "args": "tsc"
}
```

Thanks

data.title: Allow to use as Code as commit message editor in running instance
data.body:
SMALL FEATURE REQUEST :)
when I use git from the cli, I use code for commit messages and it opens a new window, it would be nice if it opened in my already open workspace.

reason for this workflow:
while I am quite happy with the git tools in code:
  - they are not as reliable in large projects.
  - I prefer to perform complicated tasks from the cli.

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12

Steps to Reproduce:
1. set git config editor to code
2. make a git commit

data.title: VSCode hangs randomly while idling

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04.2 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch VSCode and have some files in the file tree and some open in tabs.
2. Wait between 1 minute and 1 hour.  Editing files is not required.  User input is not required.
3. VSCode hangs.  Requires kill -9 of session leader PID and a restart of code.

This has been happening since 1.8 or so, but it's become much more frequent with 1.9 and 1.10.  Basically VSCode ALWAYS hangs.  It's just a matter of time.  100% reproducible.

I unloaded all my extensions but the hangs persist.  Not extension related.  Also doesn't seem related to the number of files in the file tree.  (large tree of ~4000 files and small directory with 10 files both lead to hangs)

I'm not sure which process is hanging or how to get a call stack of the hang.  Please advise and I can provide more info.

data.title: Buit-in PHP docs and intellisence
data.body: Would be great if we could have built-in PHP docs, as we do have for JS and a proper intellisence that be able to map classes and functions from my project files, besides PHP native functions.

data.title: Closing editors (tabs) can repeatedly prompt on unsaved changes
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new file (e.g. CMD + N).
2. Type some text (e.g. "foo").
3. Close the editor repeatedly (e.g. hit CMD + W multiple times)

Result:
Unsaved changes prompt appears repeatedly, once for every time you hit CMD+W.

Expected Result:
Unsaved changes prompt appears a single time.

The main use case where this is very disruptive is when you have a lot tabs open and want to close them. I often hit CMD+W many times very quickly to close out a bunch of the tabs -- but if you accidentally hit a tab that has unsaved changes, you might end up having to resolve the unsaved changes dialog many times.

I tested this in other editors, and for example Sublime Text handles this properly -- no matter how many times you hit CMD+W, you will only have to handle the dialog once.

data.title: Bad fonts rendering in editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: 10.0.14393

Hi all. Why did not anyone notice the bad rendering of the fonts in the editor? With the same settings in different editors, only in VS Code fonts are displayed poorly.

For example, Consolas with size 9px.

notepad.exe:
![notepad](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6692126/23774208/b8518216-0533-11e7-939d-07773f43ecaf.png)

Sublime Text 3:
![sublimetext3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6692126/23774214/c2714c22-0533-11e7-85e6-9a0fb4adb9c0.png)

Visual Studio 2015:
![visualstudio](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6692126/23774232/da389932-0533-11e7-9f3f-b39780812ba5.png)

Visual Sudio Code:
![visualstudiocode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6692126/23774235/df39d2b6-0533-11e7-9302-820bc7aa983e.png)

Visual Studio Code with Consolas 12px:
![visualstudiocode12px](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6692126/23774246/eae47436-0533-11e7-8f53-6f4252b3c96f.png)

As you can see, in all editors the font looks the same and awesome, except for VSCode. The font looks similar at a size of 12px, but it still looks bad.

data.title: An explicit way to restart TypeScript service (tsserver)
data.body:
VSCode sometimes displays ghost TypeScript errors, and it's not that rare in my experience. For example, I have something underlined in red in VSCode but if I run `tsc` on the project, it compiles fine.

Ideally, these situations wouldn't happen but as long as they do in practice, it would be good to have a command to reload tsserver. For example, WebStorm has this piece of UI:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/101152/23774445/f6161b26-0523-11e7-8c91-8142b144c855.png)

There is "TypeScript: Reload Project" command in VSCode but I didn't observe any effect of it.

VSCode 1.10, Windows 10.

data.title: [Feature Request]: Expose IQuickOpenService as public api
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.0
- OS Version: win10

Steps to Reproduce:

I'm trying to build an extension that presents a list of npm-packages in the command palette. As the user scrolls down the list, I would like to show a preview-html of the package's README in a virtual document (see screenshot). The existing `InputOptions` do not help me in accomplishing this. For now, I'm using `showQuickPick` but I don't think it exposes a callback for the event of user moving down the list.

This experience would be similar to how vscode accomplishes previewing a color theme when the user is browsing through the different available themes from the command palette. [This code](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/themes/electron-browser/themes.contribution.ts#L80) is what I think I need, but it is not part of the public api.

// Thanks to @hoovercj for helping me navigate through the source.

screenshot:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4213867/23774373/373c2704-04d8-11e7-9b69-0c1003cbc2f0.png)

data.title: Automatically detect .ejs templates (and other common template extensions) as HTML file
data.body:
Today, if you are working with EJS as your server side template engine for node.js, these html files have an .ejs extension. As a result, VS Code doesn't recognize by default that this is an html file and then you don't get intellisense when writing html tags. 

VS code has a drop-down at the bottom of the window that allows you to switch between treating the file as "Plain Text" to "HTML" - however, I didn't notice this drop-down right away. Ideally, for a Node.js dev, it would be nice to auto-detect some of these common extensions so that we treat them as HTML by default - .ejs is just one common extension.  There are others that we should treat the same way, such as .pug.

data.title: Expose list of valid language ids to extensions
data.body:
I apoligize if I've overlooked this, but it would be great if there was an api call that could return a list of valid language ids.

Use case: I just released an extension that allows users to configure commands that open new files with the language mode set. However, without a list of language modes available to the extension, I rely on users to configure a list of languages that they would like to create commands for. If I had a list available through the API then I could use that to automatically generate the commands I need.

data.title: "File > Save all" bug that put a file into another
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:02:52.799Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|delphi-keybindings|alefragnani|0.1.0|
|vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lonefy|0.2.2|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.6.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. You need to have 2 unsaved files, I tested it with an html (configuracion.html) file and a javascript file (configuracion.controller.js). Place the cursor in the javascript file and then go to File > Save all menu. See the attached gif.
![saveallproblem](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4131395/23771425/aa329bd6-04f5-11e7-9c29-a82a4cea6990.gif)

2. Then you will have the html file inside the javascript file.
